body: Time had expired, and the handful of fans disappeared into the frigid night. As the Brooklyn Mariners prepared for the long bus ride home, Coach Pudgie Walsh's rasp was a mere whisper. After four months of practice, pep talks and games, his team's dream of a making it to semiprofessional football's version of the Super Bowl had vanished in the New
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MARINE PARK; Coach Walsh's Drive to Semipro Championship Is Sacked

body: INDOVINO-Peter K. in his 28th year, of Syracuse and Brooklyn, NY on November 15 in Washington, D.C. in a tragic accident. Dear brother-in-law of Jill and Paul. Marathon uncle of Emma,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths INDOVINO, PETER K.

body: The Brooklyn Mariners have prevailed. They are the 1997 Garden State Football League Champions. Coached by the legendary Pudgie Walsh, the semipro team based in Marine Park beat the Connecticut Mustangs, 35-27, to win the championship on Oct. 18. But their quest continues to regain the national title they won in 1991. In the national playoffs, the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MARINE PARK; Mariners, Still Playing for Guts, Glory and No Pay, Near a Title

body: The Board of Education has discovered $70 million left over from last year's schools budget and officials said yesterday that they intended to pass on almost all of the money to the city's schools to help reduce class sizes, buy supplies and hire reading tutors. The board's disclosure of the $70 million surplus comes just two weeks after it
title: Board Finds $70 Million and Plans to Spend It on Schools

body: NOTHING stops Pudgie Walsh. Nothing. And thus, on this drowsy, sun-splashed Brooklyn morning, he could not imagine that he would be unable to break into his car trunk. He had bagels inside the trunk and it wouldn't open. His jaw was set. His mien was determined. The man was hungry. So: he jiggled the lock. He pounded the trunk. He swore at the
title: For Guts, Glory and Absolutely Nothing Else; The Ways of Pudgie Walsh: 41 Years of Neolithic Combat of the Semipro Fields of Brooklyn

body: DON'T bother to shush. This ample room, luminous in morning light that streams through a glass curtain wall, will soon be the multicultural center of the Queens Borough Public Library's Flushing branch. But for now, it is a construction site. And no librarian is going to stop the whine of a 14-inch saw buzzing through metal studs. Nor is the din
title: For Libraries, a Time of Rebirth

body: In March of 1989, the Exxon Valdez spilled 11 million gallons of oil into the pristine waters of Alaska's Prince William Sound, causing one of the worst environmental disasters in history. Yesterday in Central Park, New York City received some of the money that the Exxon Corporation paid to settle a lawsuit stemming from the spill. The money is to
title: Exxon Valdez Money to Aid City Wetlands

body: Rene Gross of Flatbush has seen a few county fairs in her day, but never one with a kosher concession stand. Sean Adams of East New York began horseback riding two years ago, but had never seen a rodeo, let alone one where almost all the cowboys were black. But there they were yesterday: Mrs. Gross pushing a stroller over an old runway at Floyd
title: Deep in the Heart of Brooklyn, Cowboys and Kosher Food

body: CARNEY-Thomas A. Died peacefully in his home on July 28 in Belle Harbor, Queens, beloved husband of Margaret (nee Rochford) and the late Thelma (nee Steventon). Until his death he was Vice President of Operations and Management for the Mendik Realty Co. where he served for 28 years. Born in Brooklyn in 1919, he served in The New York State Assembly
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CARNEY, THOMAS A.

body: WILD NEW YORK: A Guide to the Wildlife, Wild Places and Natural Phenomena of New York City By Margaret Mittelbach and Michael Crewdson Crown, 1997 It's the oldest love story in the book -- literally. Every May and June when the moon exerts its most powerful attraction, horseshoe crabs head up onto New York City's beaches for an annual rendezvous
title: At the Shoreline, Wildlife

body: A recent spate of high-profile killings may have given New Yorkers the impression that crime has been rising, but preliminary police statistics obtained yesterday show that it continued to fall throughout the city during the first half of 1997 and that the murder rate was dropping fastest of all. When the city recorded fewer than a thousand
title: Murder Rate Is Continuing To Decrease

body: Pen Thief, a copper-orange cat, is running out of lives. First, Pen Thief was kicked out of an apartment building in Coney Island by the superintendent after his owner died. Now the Brooklyn cat shelter where he and 130 other cats and a few stray rabbits have been staying for five months, Kings Highway Cat Rescue, is not only broke and expected to
title: Shelter That Was Life Raft for Stray Cats Is Floundering

title: Paid Notice: Deaths FOUST, JUDITH M.

body: Eighteen months after Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew set a goal that every third grader be able to read at grade level by now, New York City school officials acknowledged yesterday that this year's scores fell far short: while the test results were slightly higher than a year ago, more than half still could not read at the third-grade mark. Overall,
title: Despite Slight Rise, Reading Scores Fall Far Short of Goal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths O'ROURKE, DONALD F.

body: THE five-a-day program, designed by the National Cancer Institute to encourage people to eat five fruits and vegetables a day, is so far removed from the reality of what most children eat that its creators may need to go back to the drawing board and produce something more realistic. That's the only conclusion that can be drawn from reading a
title: Eating Well

body: To the 4-year-old boy, the Brooklyn Museum was a house of magic, a seemingly endless trove of huge and beautiful pictures, wondrously recreated period rooms and stunning art objects culled from civilizations from Mesopotamia to Mexico. Arnold L. Lehman, a child living in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn, visited the museum regularly with an
title: New Brooklyn Museum Chief

body: THE old trapper stopped a moment to wipe his hands, the blood staining fingerprints into his pants leg, spittle popping inside the wood-burning stove. He took up another muskrat, made two small incisions around its ankles and cut up under the tail, opening the vermin like a paper bag. Nailing its tail to the rafter, he peeled the skin back,
title: Last Days Of the Baymen

body: CASHEN-Angela. On Apr 3, 1997. Loving sister of the late James A., Alicia Hall, Madelyn Stacy, Gertrude Demarest, Edmund and Robert. Dear aunt of over 115 nieces and nephews. Funeral Sat., 10A.M. from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. Mass 11A.M. at St. Brendan's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting hours
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CASHEN, ANGELA

body: With the thunderous rattle of the Cyclone and the familiar music of carousels, Coney Island shook off winter yesterday and reopened for the summer season. But gray skies and a drizzle that deepened into rain kept all but the hardiest visitors away and meant an early journey home for the long-faced carnies, many of whom had pined for the season to
title: First Day Is Doused but Coney Island Still Swings
